1256    /**
1257     * An iterator on keys.
1258     * <p>
1259     * <P>We simply override the {@link ListIterator#next()}/{@link ListIterator#previous()} methods (and possibly their type-specific counterparts) so that they return keys
1260     * instead of entries.
1261     */
1262    public final class KeyIterator extends MapIterator implements Iterator<Integer>, Serializable {
1263        private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
1264        public Integer previous() {
1265            return key[previousEntry()];
1266        }        
1267        public int previousInt() {
1268            return key[previousEntry()];
1269        }
1270        public void set(Integer k) {
1271            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1272        }
1273        public void add(Integer k) {
1274            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1275        }
1276        public KeyIterator() {}
1277        public Integer next() {
1278            return key[nextEntry()];
1279        }
1280        public int nextInt() {
1281            return key[nextEntry()];
1282        }
1283        public void remove() { super.remove(); }
1284    }
1285
1286    public final class KeySet implements SortedSet<Integer>, Serializable {
1287        private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
1288
1289        public KeyIterator iterator() {
1290            return new KeyIterator();
1291        }
1292
1293        public int size() {
1294            return size;
1295        }
1296
1297        public void clear() {
1298            IntDoubleOrderedMap.this.clear();
1299        }
1300
1301        public Integer first() {
1302            if (size == 0) throw new NoSuchElementException();
1303            return key[order.items[0]];
1304        }
1305
1306        public Integer last() {
1307            if (size == 0) throw new NoSuchElementException();
1308            return key[order.items[order.size-1]];
1309        }
1310
1311        public Comparator<Integer> comparator() {
1312            return null;
1313        }
1314
1315        public final SortedSet<Integer> tailSet(Integer from) {
1316            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1317        }
1318
1319        public final SortedSet<Integer> headSet(Integer to) {
1320            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1321        }
1322
1323        public final SortedSet<Integer> subSet(Integer from, Integer to) {
1324            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1325        }
1326
1327        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1328        @Override
1329        public <T> T[] toArray(T[] a) {
1330            if (a == null || a.length < size()) a = (T[]) new Object[size()];
1331            unwrap(iterator(), a);
1332            return a;
1333        }
1334
1335        /**
1336         * Always throws an UnsupportedOperationException
1337         */
1338        public boolean remove(Object ok) {
1339            throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Cannot remove from the key set directly");
1340        }
1341
1342        /**
1343         * Always throws an UnsupportedOperationException
1344         */
1345        public boolean add(final Integer o) {
1346            throw new UnsupportedOperationException("Cannot add to the key set directly");
1347        }
1348
1349        /**
1350         * Delegates to the corresponding type-specific method.
1351         */
1352        public boolean contains(final Object o) {
1353            return o instanceof Integer && containsKey((Integer) o);
1354        }
1355
1356        /**
1357         * Checks whether this collection contains all elements from the given type-specific collection.
1358         *
1359         * @param c a type-specific collection.
1360         * @return <code>true</code> if this collection contains all elements of the argument.
1361         */
1362        public boolean containsAll(Collection<?> c) {
1363            final Iterator<?> i = c.iterator();
1364            int n = c.size();
1365            while (n-- != 0)
1366                if (!contains(i.next())) return false;
1367            return true;
1368        }
1369
1370        /**
1371         * Retains in this collection only elements from the given type-specific collection.
1372         *
1373         * @param c a type-specific collection.
1374         * @return <code>true</code> if this collection changed as a result of the call.
1375         */
1376        public boolean retainAll(Collection<?> c) {
1377            boolean retVal = false;
1378            int n = size();
1379            final Iterator<?> i = iterator();
1380            while (n-- != 0) {
1381                if (!c.contains(i.next())) {
1382                    i.remove();
1383                    retVal = true;
1384                }
1385            }
1386            return retVal;
1387        }
1388
1389        /**
1390         * Remove from this collection all elements in the given type-specific collection.
1391         *
1392         * @param c a type-specific collection.
1393         * @return <code>true</code> if this collection changed as a result of the call.
1394         */
1395        public boolean removeAll(Collection<?> c) {
1396            boolean retVal = false;
1397            int n = c.size();
1398            final Iterator<?> i = c.iterator();
1399            while (n-- != 0)
1400                if (remove(i.next())) retVal = true;
1401            return retVal;
1402        }
1403
1404        public Object[] toArray() {
1405            final Object[] a = new Object[size()];
1406            objectUnwrap(iterator(), a);
1407            return a;
1408        }
1409
1410        /**
1411         * Adds all elements of the given collection to this collection.
1412         *
1413         * @param c a collection.
1414         * @return <code>true</code> if this collection changed as a result of the call.
1415         */
1416        public boolean addAll(Collection<? extends Integer> c) {
1417            boolean retVal = false;
1418            final Iterator<? extends Integer> i = c.iterator();
1419            int n = c.size();
1420            while (n-- != 0)
1421                if (add(i.next())) retVal = true;
1422            return retVal;
1423        }
1424
1425        @Override
1426        public boolean equals(final Object o) {
1427            if (o == this)
1428                return true;
1429            if (!(o instanceof Set))
1430                return false;
1431            Set<?> s = (Set<?>) o;
1432            if (s.size() != size())
1433                return false;
1434            return containsAll(s);
1435        }
1436        /**
1437         * Unwraps an iterator into an array starting at a given offset for a given number of elements.
1438         * <p>
1439         * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned, up to a maximum of <code>length</code>, in the given array starting at <code>offset</code>. The
1440         * number of actually unwrapped elements is returned (it may be less than <code>max</code> if the iterator emits less than <code>max</code> elements).
1441         *
1442         * @param i      a type-specific iterator.
1443         * @param array  an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1444         * @param offset the first element of the array to be returned.
1445         * @param max    the maximum number of elements to unwrap.
1446         * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1447         */
1448        public int unwrap(final KeyIterator i, final int[] array, int offset, final int max) {
1449            if (max < 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("The maximum number of elements (" + max + ") is negative");
1450            if (offset < 0 || offset + max > array.length) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
1451            int j = max;
1452            while (j-- != 0 && i.hasNext())
1453                array[offset++] = i.nextInt();
1454            return max - j - 1;
1455        }
1456        /**
1457         * Unwraps an iterator into an array.
1458         * <p>
1459         * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned in the given array. The iteration will stop when the iterator has no more elements or when the end
1460         * of the array has been reached.
1461         *
1462         * @param i     a type-specific iterator.
1463         * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1464         * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1465         */
1466        public int unwrap(final KeyIterator i, final int[] array) {
1467            return unwrap(i, array, 0, array.length);
1468        }
1469        public int[] toIntArray() {
1470            int[] a = new int[size()];
1471            unwrap(iterator(), a);
1472            return a;
1473        }
1474
1475        public int[] toIntArray(int[] a) {
1476            if (a == null || a.length < size()) a = new int[size()];
1477            unwrap(iterator(), a);
1478            return a;
1479        }
1480
1481        /**
1482         * Unwraps an iterator into an array starting at a given offset for a given number of elements.
1483         * <p>
1484         * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned, up to a maximum of <code>length</code>, in the given array starting at <code>offset</code>. The
1485         * number of actually unwrapped elements is returned (it may be less than <code>max</code> if the iterator emits less than <code>max</code> elements).
1486         *
1487         * @param i      a type-specific iterator.
1488         * @param array  an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1489         * @param offset the first element of the array to be returned.
1490         * @param max    the maximum number of elements to unwrap.
1491         * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1492         */
1493        public int unwrap(final KeyIterator i, final Object[] array, int offset, final int max) {
1494            if (max < 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("The maximum number of elements (" + max + ") is negative");
1495            if (offset < 0 || offset + max > array.length) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
1496            int j = max;
1497            while (j-- != 0 && i.hasNext())
1498                array[offset++] = i.next();
1499            return max - j - 1;
1500        }
1501
1502        /**
1503         * Unwraps an iterator into an array.
1504         * <p>
1505         * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned in the given array. The iteration will stop when the iterator has no more elements or when the end
1506         * of the array has been reached.
1507         *
1508         * @param i     a type-specific iterator.
1509         * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1510         * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1511         */
1512        public int unwrap(final KeyIterator i, final Object[] array) {
1513            return unwrap(i, array, 0, array.length);
1514        }
1515
1516        public boolean isEmpty() {
1517            return size() == 0;
1518        }
1519
1520        @Override
1521        public String toString() {
1522            final StringBuilder s = new StringBuilder();
1523            final KeyIterator i = iterator();
1524            int n = size();
1525            boolean first = true;
1526            s.append("{");
1527            while (n-- != 0) {
1528                if (first) first = false;
1529                else s.append(", ");
1530                s.append(i.next());
1531            }
1532            s.append("}");
1533            return s.toString();
1534        }
1535    }
1536
1537    public KeySet keySet() {
1538        if (keys == null) keys = new KeySet();
1539        return keys;
1540    }
1541
1542    public OrderedSet<Integer> keysAsOrderedSet()
1543    {
1544        OrderedSet<Integer> os = new OrderedSet<>(size, f);
1545        for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
1546            os.add(keyAt(i));
1547        }
1548        return os;
1549    }
1550    public int[] keysAsArray() {
1551        return keySet().toIntArray();
1552    }
1553
1554    /**
1555     * An iterator on values.
1556     * <p>
1557     * <P>We simply override the {@link ListIterator#next()}/{@link ListIterator#previous()} methods (and possibly their type-specific counterparts) so that they return values
1558     * instead of entries.
1559     */
1560    public final class ValueIterator extends MapIterator implements ListIterator<Double>, Serializable {
1561        private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
1562
1563        public Double previous() {
1564            return value[previousEntry()];
1565        }
1566        public void set(Double v) {
1567            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1568        }
1569        public void add(Double v) {
1570            throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
1571        }
1572        public ValueIterator() {}
1573        public Double next() {
1574            return value[nextEntry()];
1575        }
1576        public void remove() { super.remove(); }
1577    }
1578    public final class ValueCollection extends AbstractCollection<Double> implements Serializable
1579    {
1580        private static final long serialVersionUID = 0L;
1581        public ValueIterator iterator() {
1582            return new ValueIterator();
1583        }
1584        public int size() {
1585            return size;
1586        }
1587        public boolean contains(Object v) {
1588            return v instanceof Double && containsValue((Double)v);
1589        }
1590        public void clear() {
1591            IntDoubleOrderedMap.this.clear();
1592        }
1593    }
1594    public Collection<Double> values() {
1595        if (values == null) values = new ValueCollection();
1596        return values;
1597    }
1598
1599    public double[] valuesAsArray()
1600    {
1601        double[] ls = new double[size];
1602        for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {
1603            ls[i] = getAt(i);
1604        }
1605        return ls;
1606    }
1607
1608    /**
1609     * Rehashes the map, making the table as small as possible.
1610     * <p>
1611     * <P>This method rehashes the table to the smallest size satisfying the load factor. It can be used when the set will not be changed anymore, so to optimize access speed and size.
1612     * <p>
1613     * <P>If the table size is already the minimum possible, this method does nothing.
1614     *
1615     * @return true if there was enough memory to trim the map.
1616     * @see #trim(int)
1617     */
1618    public boolean trim() {
1619        final int l = arraySize(size, f);
1620        if (l >= n || size > maxFill(l, f)) return true;
1621        try {
1622            rehash(l);
1623        } catch (Exception cantDoIt) {
1624            return false;
1625        }
1626        return true;
1627    }
1628
1629    /**
1630     * Rehashes this map if the table is too large.
1631     * <p>
1632     * <P>Let <var>N</var> be the smallest table size that can hold <code>max(n,{@link #size()})</code> entries, still satisfying the load factor. If the current table size is smaller than or equal to
1633     * <var>N</var>, this method does nothing. Otherwise, it rehashes this map in a table of size <var>N</var>.
1634     * <p>
1635     * <P>This method is useful when reusing maps. {@linkplain #clear() Clearing a map} leaves the table size untouched. If you are reusing a map many times, you can call this method with a typical
1636     * size to avoid keeping around a very large table just because of a few large transient maps.
1637     *
1638     * @param n the threshold for the trimming.
1639     * @return true if there was enough memory to trim the map.
1640     * @see #trim()
1641     */
1642    public boolean trim(final int n) {
1643        final int l = HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo((int) Math.ceil(n / f));
1644        if (l >= n || size > maxFill(l, f)) return true;
1645        try {
1646            rehash(l);
1647        } catch (Exception cantDoIt) {
1648            return false;
1649        }
1650        return true;
1651    }
1652
1653    /**
1654     * Rehashes the map.
1655     *
1656     * <P>
1657     * This method implements the basic rehashing strategy, and may be overriden
1658     * by subclasses implementing different rehashing strategies (e.g.,
1659     * disk-based rehashing). However, you should not override this method
1660     * unless you understand the internal workings of this class.
1661     *
1662     * @param newN
1663     *            the new size
1664     */
1665
1666    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1667    protected void rehash(final int newN) {
1668        final int[] key = this.key;
1669        final double[] value = this.value;
1670        final int mask = newN - 1; // Note that this is used by the hashing macro
1671        final int[] newKey = new int[newN + 1];
1672        final double[] newValue = new double[newN + 1];
1673        final int sz = order.size;
1674        int k;
1675        int i, pos;
1676        final int[] oi = order.items;
1677        for (int q = 0; q < sz; q++) {
1678            i = oi[q];
1679            if ((k = key[i]) == 0)
1680                pos = newN;
1681            else {
1682                pos = (HashCommon.mix(k)) & mask;
1683                while (newKey[pos] != 0)
1684                    pos = (pos + 1) & mask;
1685            }
1686            newKey[pos] = k;
1687            newValue[pos] = value[i];
1688            oi[q] = pos;
1689        }
1690        n = newN;
1691        this.mask = mask;
1692        maxFill = maxFill(n, f);
1693        this.key = newKey;
1694        this.value = newValue;
1695    }
1696    /**
1697     * Returns a deep copy of this map.
1698     *
1699     * <P>
1700     * This method performs a deep copy of this OrderedMap; the data stored in the
1701     * map, however, is not cloned. Note that this makes a difference only for
1702     * object keys.
1703     *
1704     * @return a deep copy of this map.
1705     */
1706    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1707    @GwtIncompatible
1708    public IntDoubleOrderedMap clone() {
1709        IntDoubleOrderedMap c;
1710        try {
1711            c = (IntDoubleOrderedMap) super.clone();
1712            c.key = new int[n + 1];
1713            System.arraycopy(key, 0, c.key, 0, n + 1);
1714            c.value = new double[n + 1];
1715            System.arraycopy(value, 0, c.value, 0, n + 1);
1716            c.order = order.copy();
1717            return c;
1718        } catch (Exception cantHappen) {
1719            throw new UnsupportedOperationException(cantHappen + (cantHappen.getMessage() != null ?
1720                    "; " + cantHappen.getMessage() : ""));
1721        }
1722    }
1723    /**
1724     * Returns a hash code for this map.
1725     *
1726     * @return a hash code for this map.
1727     */
1728    public int hashCode() {
1729        int h = 0;
1730        for (int j = realSize(), i = 0, t = 0; j-- != 0;) {
1731            while (key[i] == 0)
1732                i++;             
1733            t = HashCommon.mix(key[i]) ^ HashCommon.mix(
1734                    NumberTools.doubleToMixedIntBits(value[i]) ^ HashCommon.INV_INT_PHI);
1735            h += t;
1736            i++;
1737        }
1738        // Zero / null keys have hash zero.
1739        if (containsNullKey)
1740            h += HashCommon.mix(NumberTools.doubleToMixedIntBits(value[n]) ^ HashCommon.INV_INT_PHI);
1741        return h;
1742    }
1743
1744    public long hash64()
1745    {
1746        return 31L * (31L * CrossHash.hash64(key) + CrossHash.hash64(value)) + size;
1747    }
1748    /**
1749     * Returns the maximum number of entries that can be filled before rehashing.
1750     *
1751     * @param n the size of the backing array.
1752     * @param f the load factor.
1753     * @return the maximum number of entries before rehashing.
1754     */
1755    public static int maxFill(final int n, final float f) {
1756        /* We must guarantee that there is always at least
1757         * one free entry (even with pathological load factors). */
1758        return Math.min((int)(n * f + 0.99999994f), n - 1);
1759    }
1760
1761    /**
1762     * Returns the least power of two smaller than or equal to 2<sup>30</sup> and larger than or equal to <code>Math.ceil( expected / f )</code>.
1763     *
1764     * @param expected the expected number of elements in a hash table.
1765     * @param f        the load factor.
1766     * @return the minimum possible size for a backing array.
1767     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the necessary size is larger than 2<sup>30</sup>.
1768     */
1769    public static int arraySize(final int expected, final float f) {
1770        final long s = Math.max(2, HashCommon.nextPowerOfTwo((long) Math.ceil(expected / f)));
1771        if (s > (1 << 30))
1772            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Too large (" + expected + " expected elements with load factor " + f + ")");
1773        return (int) s;
1774    }
1775
1776    /**
1777     * Unwraps an iterator into an array starting at a given offset for a given number of elements.
1778     * <p>
1779     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned, up to a maximum of <code>length</code>, in the given array starting at <code>offset</code>. The
1780     * number of actually unwrapped elements is returned (it may be less than <code>max</code> if the iterator emits less than <code>max</code> elements).
1781     *
1782     * @param i      a type-specific iterator.
1783     * @param array  an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1784     * @param offset the first element of the array to be returned.
1785     * @param max    the maximum number of elements to unwrap.
1786     * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1787     */
1788    private int unwrap(final ValueIterator i, final Object[] array, int offset, final int max) {
1789        if (max < 0) throw new IllegalArgumentException("The maximum number of elements (" + max + ") is negative");
1790        if (offset < 0 || offset + max > array.length) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
1791        int j = max;
1792        while (j-- != 0 && i.hasNext())
1793            array[offset++] = i.next();
1794        return max - j - 1;
1795    }
1796
1797    /**
1798     * Unwraps an iterator into an array.
1799     * <p>
1800     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned in the given array. The iteration will stop when the iterator has no more elements or when the end
1801     * of the array has been reached.
1802     *
1803     * @param i     a type-specific iterator.
1804     * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1805     * @return the number of elements unwrapped.
1806     */
1807    private int unwrap(final ValueIterator i, final Object[] array) {
1808        return unwrap(i, array, 0, array.length);
1809    }
1810
1811
1812    /** Unwraps an iterator into an array starting at a given offset for a given number of elements.
1813     *
1814     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned, up to a maximum of <code>length</code>, in the given array starting at <code>offset</code>. The
1815     * number of actually unwrapped elements is returned (it may be less than <code>max</code> if the iterator emits less than <code>max</code> elements).
1816     *
1817     * @param i a type-specific iterator.
1818     * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1819     * @param offset the first element of the array to be returned.
1820     * @param max the maximum number of elements to unwrap.
1821     * @return the number of elements unwrapped. */
1822    private static <K> int objectUnwrap(final Iterator<? extends K> i, final K[] array, int offset, final int max ) {
1823        if ( max < 0 ) throw new IllegalArgumentException( "The maximum number of elements (" + max + ") is negative" );
1824        if ( offset < 0 || offset + max > array.length ) throw new IllegalArgumentException();
1825        int j = max;
1826        while ( j-- != 0 && i.hasNext() )
1827            array[ offset++ ] = i.next();
1828        return max - j - 1;
1829    }
1830
1831    /** Unwraps an iterator into an array.
1832     *
1833     * <P>This method iterates over the given type-specific iterator and stores the elements returned in the given array. The iteration will stop when the iterator has no more elements or when the end
1834     * of the array has been reached.
1835     *
1836     * @param i a type-specific iterator.
1837     * @param array an array to contain the output of the iterator.
1838     * @return the number of elements unwrapped. */
1839    private static <K> int objectUnwrap(final Iterator<? extends K> i, final K[] array) {
1840        return objectUnwrap(i, array, 0, array.length );
1841    }
1842
1843    @Override
1844    public String toString() {
1845        final StringBuilder s = new StringBuilder();
1846        int n = size(), i = 0;
1847        boolean first = true;
1848        s.append("IntDoubleOrderedMap{");
1849        while (i < n) {
1850            if (first) first = false;
1851            else s.append(", ");
1852            s.append(entryAt(i++));
1853        }
1854        s.append("}");
1855        return s.toString();
1856    }
1857    @Override
1858    public boolean equals(Object o) {
1859        if (o == this)
1860            return true;
1861        if (!(o instanceof IntDoubleOrderedMap))
1862            return false;
1863        IntDoubleOrderedMap m = (IntDoubleOrderedMap) o;
1864        if (m.size() != size())
1865            return false;
1866        return entrySet().containsAll(m.entrySet());
1867    }
1868
1869    @GwtIncompatible
1870    private void writeObject(java.io.ObjectOutputStream s)
1871            throws java.io.IOException {
1872        final int[] key = this.key;
1873        final double[] value = this.value;
1874        final MapIterator i = new MapIterator();
1875        s.defaultWriteObject();
1876        for (int j = size, e; j-- != 0;) {
1877            e = i.nextEntry();
1878            s.writeInt(key[e]);
1879            s.writeDouble(value[e]);
1880        }
1881    }
1882    @GwtIncompatible
1883    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1884    private void readObject(java.io.ObjectInputStream s)
1885            throws java.io.IOException, ClassNotFoundException {
1886        s.defaultReadObject();
1887        n = arraySize(size, f);
1888        maxFill = maxFill(n, f);
1889        mask = n - 1;
1890        final int[] key = this.key = new int[n + 1];
1891        final double[] value = this.value = new double[n + 1];
1892        final IntVLA order = this.order = new IntVLA(n + 1);
1893        int k;
1894        double v;
1895        for (int i = size, pos; i-- != 0;) {
1896            k = s.readInt();
1897            v = s.readDouble();
1898            if (k == 0) {
1899                pos = n;
1900                containsNullKey = true;
1901            } else {
1902                pos = (HashCommon.mix(k))
1903                        & mask;
1904                while (!(key[pos] == 0))
1905                    pos = (pos + 1) & mask;
1906            }
1907
1908            key[pos] = k;
1909            value[pos] = v;
1910            order.add(pos);
1911        }
1912    }
1913
1914    /**
1915     * Gets the value at the given index in the iteration order in constant time (random-access).
1916     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the value to fetch
1917     * @return the value at the index, if the index is valid, otherwise the default return value
1918     */
1919    public double getAt(final int idx) {
1920        int pos;
1921        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1922            return defRetValue;
1923        // The starting point.
1924        if (key[pos = order.get(idx)] == 0)
1925            return containsNullKey ? value[n] : defRetValue;
1926        return value[pos];
1927    }
1928    /**
1929     * Gets the key at the given index in the iteration order in constant time (random-access).
1930     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the key to fetch
1931     * @return the key at the index, if the index is valid, otherwise 0
1932     */
1933    public int keyAt(final int idx) {
1934        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1935            return 0;
1936        // The starting point.
1937        return key[order.get(idx)];
1938    }
1939
1940    /**
1941     * Gets the key-value Map.Entry at the given index in the iteration order in constant time (random-access).
1942     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the entry to fetch
1943     * @return the key-value entry at the index, if the index is valid, otherwise null
1944     */
1945    public MapEntry entryAt(final int idx)
1946    {
1947        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1948            return null;
1949        return new MapEntry(order.get(idx));
1950    }
1951
1952    /**
1953     * Removes the key and value at the given index in the iteration order in not-exactly constant time (though it still
1954     * should be efficient).
1955     * @param idx the index in the iteration order of the key and value to remove
1956     * @return the value removed, if there was anything removed, or the default return value otherwise (often null)
1957     */
1958    public double removeAt(final int idx) {
1959
1960        if (idx < 0 || idx >= order.size)
1961            return defRetValue;
1962        int pos = order.get(idx);
1963        if (key[pos] == 0) {
1964            if (containsNullKey)
1965                return removeNullEntry();
1966            return defRetValue;
1967        }
1968        return removeEntry(pos);
1969    }
1970    /**
1971     * Gets a random value from this OrderedMap in constant time, using the given IRNG to generate a random number.
1972     * @param rng used to generate a random index for a value
1973     * @return a random value from this OrderedMap
1974     */
1975    public double randomValue(IRNG rng)
1976    {
1977        return getAt(rng.nextInt(order.size));
1978    }
1979
1980    /**
1981     * Gets a random key from this OrderedMap in constant time, using the given IRNG to generate a random number.
1982     * @param rng used to generate a random index for a key
1983     * @return a random key from this OrderedMap
1984     */
1985    public int randomKey(IRNG rng)
1986    {
1987        return keyAt(rng.nextInt(order.size));
1988    }
1989
1990    /**
1991     * Gets a random entry from this OrderedMap in constant time, using the given IRNG to generate a random number.
1992     * @param rng used to generate a random index for a entry
1993     * @return a random key-value entry from this OrderedMap
1994     */
1995    public MapEntry randomEntry(IRNG rng)
1996    {
1997        return new MapEntry(order.getRandomElement(rng));
1998    }
1999
2000    /**
2001     * Randomly alters the iteration order for this OrderedMap using the given IRNG to shuffle.
2002     * @param rng used to generate a random ordering
2003     * @return this for chaining
2004     */
2005    public IntDoubleOrderedMap shuffle(IRNG rng)
2006    {
2007        if(size < 2)
2008            return this;
2009        order.shuffle(rng);
2010        return this;
2011    }
2012
2013    /**
2014     * Given an array or varargs of replacement indices for this OrderedMap's iteration order, reorders this so the
2015     * first item in the returned version is the same as {@code getAt(ordering[0])} (with some care taken for negative
2016     * or too-large indices), the second item in the returned version is the same as {@code getAt(ordering[1])}, etc.
2017     * <br>
2018     * Negative indices are considered reversed distances from the end of ordering, so -1 refers to the same index as
2019     * {@code ordering[ordering.length - 1]}. If ordering is smaller than {@code size()}, only the indices up to the
2020     * length of ordering will be modified. If ordering is larger than {@code size()}, only as many indices will be
2021     * affected as {@code size()}, and reversed distances are measured from the end of this Map's entries instead of
2022     * the end of ordering. Duplicate values in ordering will produce duplicate values in the returned Map.
2023     * <br>
2024     * This method modifies this OrderedMap in-place and also returns it for chaining.
2025     * @param ordering an array or varargs of int indices, where the nth item in ordering changes the nth item in this
2026     *                 Map to have the value currently in this Map at the index specified by the value in ordering
2027     * @return this for chaining, after modifying it in-place
2028     */
2029    public IntDoubleOrderedMap reorder(int... ordering)
2030    {
2031        order.reorder(ordering);
2032        return this;
2033    }
2034    private int alterEntry(final int pos) {
2035        int idx = fixOrder(pos);
2036        size--;
2037        shiftKeys(pos);
2038        return idx;
2039    }
2040    private int alterNullEntry() {
2041        int idx = fixOrder(n);
2042        containsNullKey = false;
2043        size--;
2044        return idx;
2045    }
2046    /**
2047     * Swaps a key, original, for another key, replacement, while keeping replacement at the same point in the iteration
2048     * order as original and keeping it associated with the same value (which also keeps its iteration index). Unlike
2049     * the similar method {@link #alter(int, int)}, this will not change this OrderedMap if replacement is already
2050     * present. To contrast, alter() can reduce the size of the OrderedMap if both original and replacement are already
2051     * in the Map. If replacement is found, this returns the default return value, otherwise it switches out original
2052     * for replacement and returns whatever was associated with original.
2053     * @param original the key to find and swap out
2054     * @param replacement the key to replace original with
2055     * @return the value associated with original before, and replacement now
2056     */
2057    public double alterCarefully(final int original, final int replacement) {
2058        if(!containsKey(replacement))
2059            return alter(original, replacement);
2060        else
2061            return defRetValue;
2062    }
2063    /**
2064     * Swaps a key, original, for another key, replacement, while keeping replacement at the same point in the iteration
2065     * order as original and keeping it associated with the same value (which also keeps its iteration index).
2066     * Be aware that if both original and replacement are present in the OrderedMap, this will still replace original
2067     * with replacement but will also remove the other occurrence of replacement to avoid duplicate keys. This can throw
2068     * off the expected order because the duplicate could be at any point in the ordering when it is removed. You may
2069     * want to prefer {@link #alterCarefully(int, int)} if you don't feel like checking by hand for whether
2070     * replacement is already present, but using this method is perfectly reasonable if you know overlaps won't happen.
2071     * @param original the key to find and swap out
2072     * @param replacement the key to replace original with
2073     * @return the value associated with original before, and replacement now
2074     */
2075    public double alter(final int original, final int replacement) {
2076        double v;
2077        int idx;
2078        if (original == 0) {
2079            if (containsNullKey) {
2080                v = value[n];
2081                idx = alterNullEntry();
2082                putAt(replacement, v, idx);
2083                return v;
2084            }
2085            else
2086                v = defRetValue;
2087            return v;
2088        }
2089        int curr;
2090        final int[] key = this.key;
2091        int pos;
2092        // The starting point.
2093        if ((curr = key[pos = (HashCommon.mix(original)) & mask]) == 0)
2094            return defRetValue;
2095        if (original == curr)
2096        {
2097            v = value[pos];
2098            idx = alterEntry(pos);
2099            putAt(replacement, v, idx);
2100            return v;
2101        }
2102        while (true) {
2103            if ((curr = key[pos = (pos + 1) & mask]) == 0)
2104                return defRetValue;
2105            if (original == curr)
2106            {
2107                v = value[pos];
2108                idx = alterEntry(pos);
2109                putAt(replacement, v, idx);
2110                return v;
2111            }
2112        }
2113    }
2114
2115    public double[] getMany(int... keys)
2116    {
2117        if(keys == null || keys.length == 0)
2118            return new double[0];
2119        final int len = keys.length;
2120        double[] vals = new double[len];
2121        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
2122            vals[i] = get(keys[i]);
2123        }
2124        return vals;
2125    }
2126    /**
2127     * Changes the int at the given index to replacement while keeping replacement at the same point in the ordering.
2128     * Be aware that if replacement is present in the OrderedMap, this will still replace the given index
2129     * with replacement but will also remove the other occurrence of replacement to avoid duplicate keys. This can throw
2130     * off the expected order because the duplicate could be at any point in the ordering when it is removed. You may
2131     * want to prefer {@link #alterAtCarefully(int, int)} if you don't feel like checking by hand for whether
2132     * replacement is already present, but using this method is perfectly reasonable if you know overlaps won't happen.
2133     * @param index       an index to replace the int key at
2134     * @param replacement another int key that will replace the original at the remembered index
2135     * @return the value associated with the possibly-altered key
2136     */
2137    public double alterAt(int index, int replacement)
2138    {
2139        return alter(keyAt(index), replacement);
2140    }
2141    /**
2142     * Changes the int at the given index to replacement while keeping replacement at the same point in the ordering.
2143     * Unlike the similar method {@link #alterAt(int, int)}, this will not change this OrderedMap if replacement is
2144     * already present. To contrast, alterAt() can reduce the size of the OrderedMap if replacement is already
2145     * in the Map. If replacement is found, this returns the default return value, otherwise it switches out the index
2146     * for replacement and returns whatever value was at the index before.
2147     * @param index       an index to replace the int key at
2148     * @param replacement another int key that will replace the original at the remembered index
2149     * @return the value associated with the key at the altered index before, and replacement now
2150     */
2151    public double alterAtCarefully(int index, int replacement)
2152    {
2153        return alterCarefully(keyAt(index), replacement);
2154    }
2155
2156    /**
2157     * If the specified key is not already associated with a value, associates it with the given value
2158     * and returns that value, else returns the current value without changing anything.
2159     *
2160     * @param key   key with which the specified value is to be associated
2161     * @param value value to be associated with the specified key
2162     * @return the previous value associated with the specified key, or
2163     * {@code value} if there was no mapping for the key.
2164     */
2165    public double putIfAbsent(int key, double value) {
2166        if(containsKey(key))
2167            return get(key);         
2168        put(key, value);
2169        return value;
2170    }
2171
2172    /**
2173     * Removes the entry for the specified key only if it is currently
2174     * mapped to the specified value.
2175     *
2176     * @param key   key with which the specified value is associated
2177     * @param value value expected to be associated with the specified key
2178     * @return {@code true} if the value was removed
2179     */
2180    public boolean remove(int key, double value) {
2181        if (containsKey(key) && get(key) == value) {
2182            remove(key);
2183            return true;
2184        } else
2185            return false;
2186    }
2187
2188    /**
2189     * Replaces the entry for the specified key only if currently
2190     * mapped to the specified value. The position in the iteration
2191     * order is retained.
2192     *
2193     * @param key      key with which the specified value is associated
2194     * @param oldValue value expected to be associated with the specified key
2195     * @param newValue value to be associated with the specified key
2196     * @return {@code true} if the value was replaced
2197     */
2198    public boolean replace(int key, double oldValue, double newValue) {
2199        if (containsKey(key) && get(key) == oldValue) {
2200            put(key, newValue);
2201            return true;
2202        } else
2203            return false;
2204    }
2205
2206    /**
2207     * Replaces the entry for the specified key only if it is
2208     * currently mapped to some value. Preserves the existing key's
2209     * position in the iteration order.
2210     *
2211     * @param key   key with which the specified value is associated
2212     * @param value value to be associated with the specified key
2213     * @return the previous value associated with the specified key, or
2214     * {@code null} if there was no mapping for the key.
2215     * (A {@code null} return can also indicate that the map
2216     * previously associated {@code null} with the key.)
2217     */
2218    public double replace(int key, double value) {
2219        if (containsKey(key)) {
2220            return put(key, value);
2221        } else
2222            return defRetValue;
2223    }
2224}
